A design that seems flashy and flexible on the surface, but turns out to be really creaky and stiff. Most games go nowhere because one player accumulates most of the coins, freezing up the other players, ironically making this more pro-banker than Pax Renaissance. You could fight a war, but it takes way more actions just to move around properly. Once in a while there's some crazy tabletalk and bizarre deals, but they're very rare. The vast majority of games (especially when someone's learning) it just hums a little and then stops in the middle of the road. And then everyone says it's a nice design but never wants to play again.

I think what bothers me most is how every card is a mishmash of icons, covered by the excuse that players don't know what's happening in this part of history. Hrm, I can't say anyone walks out of the game understanding that better either. Everyone's an intelligence/economic shadowy mastermind who doesn't directly get involved, and it's kind of weird indirect storytelling. If you just wanted to play a war or economic game, there's games that get to both ends faster, but here there's not even much overlap in the middle where they meet either.

Even with players who know the game very well, there's not much theme involved. Just bean-counting. Yay.

After 1 play this seemed right up my alley, lots of cool abilities, interesting and unique mechanisms, cool components.

But after playing again, this is a classic illusion of agency game, it's largely just random nonsense.

Cards come out giving a draft of limited agency. You will want to do very specific things on your turns, but unfortunately on you turn, good options for you may be available or they may not. They may be cheaper or more expensive, but this is out of your control.

Player interaction is way too high, you can defend yourself to some extent, but defence is way weaker than attack and getting attacked can be utterly crippling.

All this boils down to, is a pure kingmaker game, the person who gets attacked the least will just win, the person who cops the most will just lose. What's even more miserable is that often people will attack you just because they can, not because they really need or want to.

Way too long of an affair for how often a player is left with little to no agency while swimming amongst a broad array of ever-changing, yet often irrelevant and/or unappealing options. Unlike Arcs, which has a limited scope from round to round that can be strategized around with clever play and use of the tools provided, here it just feels like I’m along for the ride on the market, with little to no control, and a complete inability to plan for anything. If something is accomplished on my turn, it’s completely unsatisfying, both because what happened feels so arbitrary as to make me feel *I* didn’t really do anything, and because something else arbitrary is about to completely erase it.

This might be brilliant game for those, who really wants to get into a fight over dominance, calculating the costs against either against own benefits or harm to opponents. I see the potential, but I'm simply not in the targeted group of confrontational game players, other than competitive games. This might be read as a clear warning as well as a hint to invest in other opinions of players within the target group.

Great design. Feels super tense and thematic in a way that reminds me of Twilight Struggle. It felt like every move was painful and even the most clever things were just enough to keep your head above water for a second or two. Maybe the one thing that separates it from Twilight Struggle (which I like) is that TS often gives you hope in the form of good cards or a good dice roll to mix in with the agony/despair, and sometimes you even get some good stuff on your opponents' turns. There's also the metagame of the fog of war cardplay that makes it feel more like a fun game. I'm not sure if there's anything in Pax Pamir that made me feel good or like I was having fun, which is still something that's pretty important to me when picking/playing a game.

I don't see how this game doesn't come down to pure and simple kingmaking. I don't mind games like root where kingmaking is a big part of the game if the other things that you do are fun and develop your own board state and have some kind of other skill expression, but I felt the mechanisms in this game did not justify the game experience and that it is going to boil down to kingmaking far too much of the time. Part of this is because of the family feud style scoring that doubles scores in the final round, making it more important than other rounds.

I was glad that I played this game as it gave me some perspective into how both root and arcs came to be, which are both games that I appreciate and like a ton. I just think that I would rather play those games to get a better version of the experience that this game offered me.

Great art and components complement a mind-bending tactical puzzle. I don't have an issue with that in a quick game like Innovation, but in a game of this length, an opponent undoing several of your turns with only one of theirs is very disappointing. The King is Dead 2e does a very similar puzzle to this, in a much shorter time, without nearly the same amount of friction points. It also doesn't help that Pax Pamir's rules are very complex due to the interplay of systems, which makes revisiting the game infrequently a challenging endeavor.
I do think Cole Wehrle is a genius, you can tell how much love he has put into this game and his other games, I just don't click with his designs.

Initial Impression after 3 Solo-Games:

Pros:
+ Very interactive boardgame design
+ Interesting and unique mechanics of influencing neutral factions and tableu building
+ Game bot for the Solo game is good

Cons:
- I don't like the artwork and the cloth gameboard
- Too many fiddely, small rules, which are also similar to each other but on the other hand different enough to get you confused
- This is a big one: VERY CONSTRAINED, NO STRATEGY POSSIBLE! Too little player agency due to action mechanic and high card draw randomness / card market order: You do actions through cards that have to be: available AND affordable OR through cards you already have in play (which, as just described, were acquired semi-randomly) OR through bonus actions through a trump suit, usually determined by other players. In short, you often choose the lesser of a couple of evils and you are unable to make your own plans. It's possible that cards you've planned to use are bought by others, or that not a single available card fits your plans and other cards are not affordable to buy or to play.
- The game is way too chaotic for it's length
- "Killing / Capturing cards" is a very frustrating kind of "take that" mechanic
- During dominance check all the troops are wiped off the map so everyone has to start from the beginning. Of course it is important for preventing a runaway leader, but it doesn't feel satisfying for me.
- The whole Gameplay tends to be a "Tug of war" with doing and undoing, i don't ussally like it. Beyond that the last Domination Check is doubled, so a lame tug of war game will be won by just dominating the last round? Really???
- Diplomacy falls flat, because it is mostly about money
- You constantly have to read all the card effects of your opponents written in small font, because this cards change too often so you can't just memoize them all.


Verdict: The negative points described above say it all... not a game for me and my playing group.

This is the most accessible game in the Pax series and the best production quality by far. The Pax engine is simply great, the character of each game is totally different and can change multiple times even in the same session. Loops commonly emerge that can cause the game state to be locked into a positive feedback cycle careening the game into a deterministic death spiral, which is fascinating and rewarding to engineer such effects if it can win you the game. The multi-dimensional nature of blocks on the map and spies on the courts and its indirect connectivity gives the game ample depth and many levers to pull to influence the nature of the struggle during gameplay and bend opponents to your will. Outside of the Pax system, how many other games feature such as sandbox-like fluid dynamism?

Ultimately it's a card game so there is luck of the draw involved, and like other Eklundian games, it is more tactical, or rather opportunistic, than strategic. Good play involves exploiting temporary relative imbalances or advantages, and if you are are not in such a position, steering the game into a new direction is a strong incentive. Sometimes it is possible to build an engine of sorts but it might only lasts for a few turns as a clever opponent can counter through various ways. In an apparent validation of chaos theory, you can inadvertently change the game state in drastic ways.

Weird things happen when all players are aligned to the same power. The closed economy creates bizarre situations; without money, which can leave the game pretty quickly never to return, then gifts, betrayals, and builds are useless. Then again, with loans from the great powers (leveraged impact icons), money can suddenly boom into the economy and a purchase-build-tax cycle emerges. It might be best to have a court of non-patriots to maintain allegiance flexibility. Or sometimes you might need to betray one of your own courtiers to jump on the bandwagon of a surging coalition. A potent play is to manipulate the discard down to hand and court size rule, it is a great way to kill enemy spies, trash cards that you can use a single shot, so discarding is yet another mechanism for manipulating the game state. When every player is aligned to a different faction then it becomes a death match, as any player to achieve dominance with a faction will instantly win (five points immediately pushes a player above the victory threshold).

Update: after 15 plays it seems like the scoring system limits the narrative and dynamism typical of the other Pax games, and allows for strategies and gamesmanship that seems to be against the ethos of the Pax series. I have a simple formula that seems unbeatable, the most likely outcome is no coalition is dominant, so get the most pieces in play (and have the most political cards to get a big tableau size to allow you to get more pieces out) and score the most by having the most pieces on the map, it's an effective and boring way to win.

Update: 20 plays in and I have cooled on this game and probably Cole Wehrle's designs overall which are overtly opinionated, usually a scathing critique of British imperialism or capitalism, and I am not interested in discussing this during a board game. The game is beautiful and overproduced and though this a dumb reason, I think this is a draw back for me as I lean towards the Winsome or GaryGarison PNP aesthetic where good designs hide behind ugly and unassuming presentations. In a ranking of the Pax games I put this one close to the bottom: 1) Renaissance 2) Porfiriana 3) Lords of the Spanish Main 4) Transhumanity 5) Pamir 6) Emancipation.

Played two games today, ngl Im impressed by design choices. I really enjoy the thematic aspect where you are changing alliance to fractions instead of leading the fraction itself. I really enjoy the shared banks mechanics in games as it makes the resource menagment even more important. The taxing and bribe mechanics to use or place cards on the dominated regions is pretty cool. The amount of choices and ways to get the advantage is very vast. Dominating a region with tribes aint enough when the leader card in your tablo ain't protected. You have to constantly balance many factors. The mechanic of buying cards outta market is also pretty interesting making you pay the price for something you want quicker. Actions menagment linked to just 2 action per turn + bonus action if suits matching cards is also pretty nice making the game very volitile for burst turns, also making people over reliable on one suit suffer. This game have few of mechanics I really like in one box, a big variaty in numbers of cards, and overall is a really great title. Definitly gonna grab a copy when possible

The bot is pretty straightforward and the overall rules are pretty easy. There are just a few rules which are easy to miss. The player aids are very helpful and the game quality is amazing.

Many negative reviews mention the randomness of the market and that you are not able to plan ahead. I don't think so. Yes, the market is random (which is a great aspect - every game is different), but it is always possible to plan with what you get and the bot/players getting in your way is part of the ride. I went into this game with very little awareness of the historical period, but with an appreciation for Cole Wehrle's design sensibilities. It has become a firm favourite.

Its closed economy, shifting alliances, and a very intriguing point system always leave an impression. Reading the suggested material from the rulebook has further enhanced my enjoyment of the game!
I appreciate every game from this designer and this is his best work (that I've played).

Holy cow, this is good! And it's beautiful. Can't wait to try other Pax games since people whose opinion I trust think the others are even better. The only thing that gives me pause is the doubled scoring in the final dominance check.

Played over 100 times now and I can say this game is nearly perfect, especially in 4 player.

I love the tension between the necessary short game, not letting anyone win by 4, and the long game, knowing the final dominance check counts double. Not to mention within each dominance check the tension between cooperation with another player under a nation flag or just focusing on your own tribes/spies/economy and not sticking your neck out.

So many different styles of play and so many ways it can grind to a (sometimes heartbreaking) finish as everyone waits for the last dominance card to make its appearance. Almost always a thrill.

Why I love it?
-Gorgeous components.
-Fun game to play.
-Very interactive: decisions have ramifications that impact others directly or indirectly, with a nearly closed economy.
-Thematic: the player feels the need to ride the waves of political (cards/cylinders) and military (blocks) change.
-Elegant game with simple rules (the multiplayer rules) and interesting decisions.
-Very replayable. While the strategy is quite static: just get more points, the turn to turn gameplay is very variable and presents unique decisions.
-When all players are competent, certain advantages in different fields emerge (one may have more coins, another more influence, another more discs), and whoever leverages this best can win.

Some of its limitations:
-Looks like an area control wargame, but plays more like a political simulation in which there happen to be military units which can seldomly be used for combat. At times, there is more action with the spy cylinders that can attack, betray and even be discarded alongside a card.
-Restricted actions: while there is little movement, you are limited to where you put your pieces, which in turn limits the scope of battles/betrays and taxes/bribes. The tableau and market allows you or does not allow you to make a specific play.
-Build action is underpowered.
-Best when all players are similarly strong and understanding of the implication of their moves. Bad players will be left behind and may ruin the game as they can serve plays in a silver platter for the stronger players (the most common being not stopping an imminent victory and leaving 3 star cards or strong 2 star cards for other players).
-Player sitting order is important. Seating after a weak player is an advantage and after a strong a disadvantage, which is the opposite of a handicap.
-In some games, a player can hoard coins. While a valid strategy in some cases and for a time, it can slow down the game and makes other players have way less options.

Player Scaling:
More strategic, or at least a sense of it as there are less external influences at 3p, more chaotic at 5p, while the intended shifting alliances work better at 4-5p. Not a bad game at 2-3, just that it doesn't have that shifting alliances gameplay in focus. Player count specific disadvantages:
-(1p) Bot has lots of rules and, for some, needs extra unofficial rules to be more of a challenge.
-(1-2p) Shifting alliances impacting players is lost.
-(1-3p) Combat is less common.
-(3-5p) Kingmaking: no mechanisms to counter this. Even goes above with 'Kingpaving': bad moves by any player can give another a big advantage. Cards feel predetermined in the market.
-(4-5p) Little control over the market. Reduced strategic play as the market and game state fluctuate more wildly between turns. If a player is too strong but it is away from you in sitting order then you can't attack their cards with spies easily.
-(5p): A problem with 5p is that it is very susceptible to a flock behavior where everyone aligns with one faction and have no incentive/are punished to go against everyone else.

Alternatives:
-At 2-3p, it is like Ankh: both very deterministic area control games and euro-wargame hybrids. You can math out moves, especially towards the endgame. Both are more strategic at lower player counts and then become more tactical instead as player count increases.
-The Expanse Board Game.
-COIN games, like Fire in the Lake, with their semi-randomized victory checks.
